comments.commentBody:
Twitter is truly "the reptilian medium for the reptilian brain" and the comparison to porn is very apt in that regard.
Stephens also notes that this medium is "ideally suited for his style of crowd politics." Actually it is ideally suited for the Trump crowd. They believe and swallow everything he says and then un-says, all within the same speech, sometime within the same breath. His lawyer, who recently said that Trump was and wasn't under investigation, must have his job for that one supreme capacity - to say two opposites with a straight face.
Trup supporters are truly a living example of Schrödinger's cat, the dead and the undead. They believe Wall Street folks are bad, very bad, but will applaud when droves of them are appointed to the cabinet. They believe in building a wall at Mexico's expense, until they are told that making it with solar panels, on our public dime, will offset Mexico's costs.
I have stopped blaming Trump. He is just a puppeteer who knows his puppets. The blame is on those who voted for him and continue to support him, but the joke is on ALL of us.

It may have been a few centuries ago, but boy did the Bard-of-Avon know human behavior. And we haven't changed one bit in that period.

Sad, very sad.

comments.commentBody:
"The politics of scandal is delightful for cable news."
This is an accurate but sad observation about our collective ethos today. On the one hand we, the readers and viewers, bemoan the lack of substance in reportage. But we do not tune in when detailed analysis of a policy is presented. On the other hand, we come in droves to the venue where the latest scandal or leak is being presented. The media, while not entirely blameless, can't be faulted for feeding their readership what apparently they seem to want.

But, having said that, I do think that Brooks gives 45 a big pass. He notes, almost in passing, that "Donald Trump rose peddling the politics of scandal," but quickly moves on to note that "people who hype the politics of scandal don’t make American government purer." In other words, he's channeling Michelle Obama - "When they go low, we go high." Look what it did to Hillary Clinton. But before that, look what it did to Ted Cruz, Marco Rubio, and jeb Bush. All of them, and many others, were swallowed by the cess pool of Donald trump.

It may make you feel superior, but going high when they go low, ain't winning anyone any office.

comments.commentBody:
"The country’s real silent majority prefers Democrats, if only that majority could be stirred to vote."

This is a sad commentary on progressive folk who may lean more toward Democrats but are too lazy to get out and vote.

I recall the Pottery barn rule formulated by then Secretary Colin Powell - "You break it, you buy it," meaning that you are responsible for any kind of intrusion.

Not voting is the reverse of intrusion; it demonstrates lack of interest and apathy. And if one is uninterested and apathetic, then one loses the privilege of complaining.

You don't vote, you can't criticize.

comments.commentBody:
Bret Stephens writes, "I wish liberals would be more forthright and say it’s the amendment that needs to change, not the size of magazine clips."

I too wish more of us will come out and say that the second amendment was passed way back when the concept of militias was important and the musket was the technologically most advanced gun available. And, it needs to change. And that is what is being proposed by many sane people, including Gail Collins in this column, who are merely asking for some regulation that recognizes the way we live these days. We have become far more urban-centric that requires mass transportation more than guns. And, as for organizing a militia, good luck to those who wish to fight the U.S. Army with its tanks and missiles.

So, the bottom line is that we need to have sensible regulations about gun ownership and use, no more or no less than those in regards car ownership and use. We need to register our car, take a test to be fit to drive on the roads, and renew these at frequent intervals. It is only a vocal minority, even in the NRA, that is opposed to any rational sensible regulation. the majority NRA members favor sensible regulations.

comments.commentBody:
"Why this combination of secrecy and speed?"

Secrecy, because they are worried that any ray of light will act like a disinfectant and clean the entire bill. All nocturnal animals fear daylight, so do Republicans.

Speed, because it is difficult to impossible to see the sleight of hand. All magicians use speed and shift the viewer's focus elsewhere as they perform their tricks. So do Republicans.

Nocturnal animals live through the night to survive, magicians use speed and sleight of hand to entertain, whereas Republicans use secrecy and speed to inflict pain and harm.

comments.commentBody:
It has become normal to talk ONLY about comity and "Coming Together" rather than gun related legislation after any tragedy.
After all "if 20 little children can be shot in their Connecticut school without triggering national gun law reform," why should we expect anything different now.
Like Trump has made telling lies the new normal, the NRA has successfully made buying and owning more guns the new normal. This, in spite of the fact that the overwhelming majority of Americans, including a majority of NRA members, want sane sensible reform and restrictions on gun sales.
So, what gives? For one, our representatives are in the pocket of the NRA since they are getting significant financial support from it. Only an active minority of NRA members are opposed to such legislation, but, boy are they active. So, second, we need to get more vocal and active. After all we are in the majority. But since we are silent, we are not heard.
So, call and your representative every single week, at least once, if not thrice. Write him/her at least once a month. Do not stop that until you see some movement.
The only way to overcome the active minority is to become the active majority.

comments.commentBody:
In the abstract there is nothing about "cultural appropriation" that cannot be better and more palatably described as "cultural assimilation." And in that sense there is nothing inherently wrong or malicious about cultural appropriation.

But, just like in so many other cases, it all depends on the tone and context. Is it being done to malign or celebrate a culture? is it being done to highlight or marginalize a culture's contributions? Is it being done tastefully or tastelessly?

As always, the devil is in the details. There is no arguing the abstract notion but there is every reason to critically review every instance of it.

comments.commentBody:
Ms. May's statements and positions are risible and she deserves much blame for weakening her hand in future Brexit negotiations. Her alternate, Boris Johnson, does not exactly infuse confidence.

But do not underestimate the stupidity of the British voters. Just like Americans got conned into voting a con man into the WH, the ill informed British voter got conned into Brexit.

The most stunning lesson from these two improbable results - Brexit and trump - is that many citizens in the west are ill informed and poorly educated in spite of being citizens in rich western democracies. It is time for us in the west to stop laughing at those poor people in South Asia, Middle east and Africa who seem to know much more about themselves and their countries, and are hampered by post colonial conditions rather than inherent ignorance.

comments.commentBody:
In a war theater I've often seen the term "collateral damage" applied to identify innocent bystanders lose their lives or property. It is a term intended to varnish over the ugly reality and brutality of war. We gloss over the issue of whether it was "fair" or "unfair" for bystanders to lose their lives and property.

But I've never heard that in the context of tax policy. Efforts to modify our tax structure have invariably included the notion of fairness and progressiveness. This is the first time that I've seen fairness being sacrificed in favor of "growth and efficiency." I was chilled to my bones just reading Mr. Stephens' words cited here below.

"And our debates about tax policy should be about growth and efficiency, not fairness."

comments.commentBody:
Mr. Brooks reaches all the way back to 1917 to teach us about radicalism, only leftist radicalism.

Coincidentally that was also the time of the Russian revolution that set the beginning of what eventually became the Soviet Union resulting in the many decades of the cold war with the west. No mention of that, but I understand that he was focusing only in the revolutionary forces operating in America.

If the boundaries of his analysis were defined by the Atlantic and Pacific coasts, how about other revolutions on the right? What about the McCarthy period of anti-communism that took on ominous proportions? What about the silent revolution led by St. Reagan who famously opined that "government was the problem" even as he was seeking to lead the government? What about the Koch brothers funded Tea Party opposition to the first African American POTUS?

I urge Mr. brooks to be more inclusive in his analysis of revolutions in America. Isn't he interested in OTOH aspects??

comments.commentBody:
Anther deserved setback to the Trump craziness.
Lost in all of these is the fact that when Trump and his goons first issued the executive order, and Trump signed it with much fanfare, he said that it was important to have this ban since it was in the interest of our country's security. He added that it was critical to stop the incessant flow of Muslims and immigrants who only want to commit crimes once they are in here. Without the ban, he opined that we would have imminent danger.
Lo and behold, we have had more danger spewing from the WH and DJT than from Muslims or immigrants. In of itself, that negates every single rationale for this ban.

comments.commentBody:
"And the main point of the Pax Americana, the best case for all the money we spend maintaining it, is that it promises to keeps a lid on exactly these sorts of regional conflicts — by variously reassuring, cowing and protecting nations that would otherwise be engaged in arms races and shooting wars."

The key words here are "the money we spend maintaining it" and "promises to keep a lid on exactly these sorts of regional conflicts." Since the middle of the past century, Pax America has has been maintained with American "spending" resulting in the deep and wide influence it has brought us in return, besides, of course, the relative peace compared to the turmoil that roiled the world the previous two or more centuries.

This is an idea that the POTUS does not seem to understand as he goes around the world asking people to pay their fair share of global defense. He does not understand that one of the reasons he is welcome all around the world is that he is the leader of Pax Americana, and were the rest of the world "on their own," neither would he be as welcome nor would there be the kind of relative tranquil that prevails now.

Maybe we should put it in simpler terms, those that he might understand. "Sir, they are pledging their friendship and loyalty as long as we are buying their dinner."

comments.commentBody:
The title of this column is misleading. It seems to suggest that the voters are reckless. Maybe, just maybe, and I'll say that only grudgingly. Why? Because we have feckless leaders who willfully lie. The Brexit campaign and The Donald's campaign were filled with lies, outright lies. And the spineless party and supine media participated in this feast rather than calling out the lies. Yes, the voters are ultimately responsible, but they were fed falsity.
And now, members of the party "have become accomplices in this project of their own intellectual and moral debasement." Thankfully the media has woken up from their collective stupor.
And now I hope the public is awake, wide enough to give a knockout punch to the lying demagogues in 2018.

comments.commentBody:
"The American presidency is, in many ways, sort of elected monarchy, in which a temperamentally and intellectually unqualified leader can do immense damage."

This comment - that the American presidency is an elected monarchy - made me wince, but upon reflection it is utterly true. There is no way to remove the president other than impeachment, which is an unlikely proposition. There is no parliament that can debate a no-confidence motion. We put a person in office and hope that he (no she as yet) performs his constitutionally mandated duties well. And, as we are witnessing on a daily basis, our faith is being challenged.

comments.commentBody:
Justice Felix Frankfurter opined, correctly, I might add, that they, the judges, cannot pretend to be ignorant to what they know and see as common citizens, which all of us, no matter our professions, are.
While there may be many judges with such "common sense" spread across our judiciary, we'll need five on the SCOTUS with that kind of wisdom to successfully oppose POTUS on the travel ban issue. I do not have much faith in the newly elected Gorsuch, nor do I have much hope for Anthony Kennedy to be the fifth sane justice. Will it be CJ Roberts, who, after all, did cast the crucial fifth vote in helping salvage Obamacare many years ago?

comments.commentBody:
All your goals - heart, hand, head, and soul (dangerously close to the 4H program) - are laudable and worthy of support. I wish you luck in your hedge fund endeavor.
But, even as I applaud you for your generous gifting of the hypothetical billions, I think a far more significant solution would be to reduce the income disparity. This would have a wider, greater, and deeper effect on the nurture and access so desperately needed by those in the bottom rungs of the economic ladder As you pledge your billions are you ready to simultaneously endorse a plan to tax the rich at higher levels?

comments.commentBody:
As Douthat notes, "Trump was forthright, not deceptive."
This was true not only in case of is bent toward Russia but also in case of his misogyny, racism, incest, and bigotry. Yet he was sent to the WH, with a thin margin, not in the popular vote but in the EC.

This tells us more about ourselves than the man in the WH. It tells us that as a nation we are willing to tolerate all of the aforesaid evils and that racism and sexism are well and alive in large parts of the country. It tells us that repeatedly hammering a nonissue, such as Hillary Clinton's emails, the GOP successfully torpedoed her candidacy because of uninformed or under-informed voters. It tells us that being smart, intelligent, thoughtful, cogent, or coherent are not even remotely thought to be essential characteristics for holding higher office. It tells us that boorish and empty braggadocio sells.

Even as this makes me angry and sad, I hold out hope that the elections in 2018 will turn the tide.

comments.commentBody: While this is all good news there are dark clouds hanging over state universities. Many of the top state universities are forced to raise private funds in order to plug the void in the drop from state funds making me wonder if they are still state universities other than in name. The effect of increased state support for their flagship universities will go a much longer way in bridging this class divide.

comments.commentBody:
"Trump was the gateway candidate."
Absolutely, positively YES!
If, after the release of the "Access Hollywood" tapes in which Trump acknowledges groping and sexually assaulting women;
If, after claiming that he could shoot anyone on Fifth Avenue with no drop in public support;
If, after mimicking a reporter with disability;
If, after publicly shaming John McCain for getting caught by the enemy;
If, after criticizing a Gold Star family;
If, after all of these and many more, far too many to be listed here, Trump went from candidate to POTUS, and continues to enjoy the support of nearly 90% of those who voted for him, it is we the people who have to look in the mirror and ask, "Are we the gateway people facilitating the moral, social, and political decay of America?"

comments.commentBody:
According to Brooks, the multicultural narrative "values inclusion, but doesn't answer the question, Included into what?"
This implies that those of us who are secular and believe in multiculturalism need to define a larger entity into which all of us fit. Why is it so necessary to find that larger entity? Can I not be a white Christian male and acknowledge that there are black Muslim females? Or a brown Arab male? And leave it simply at that? Are we so dumb as to need a larger fishbowl into which we fit all the smaller fishbowls?
And maybe that is just the problem - the inability of many Americans who desperately need to fit their identity into something larger. And maybe that is just why "America First" - a simple narrative that made all "others" fit into the white-Christian-male resonated with a large segment of Americans.

comments.commentBody: Of course Trump views himself as the state. This was known before, at least to the many of us who shunned him in the polls last November. You see, people failed to understand that translating his so-called business experience and so-called business success were incorrect. He never worked for a publicly traded company where the CEO may be in charge but is answerable to the board and shareholders. He was the head of a family business where he could afford to be judge, jury, and executioner. He is now realizing that there are many shackles placed on any branch of the government, including the executive branch, and he cannot rule by fiat. This is not a family enterprise where the civil servants are his property.

comments.commentBody:
"What's the matter with Republicans?"
Let me tell you what's the matter with Republicans.
For one, they are gutless, spineless, and heartless folks. They have no room for empathy, leave alone sympathy. That's why they will cut taxes on the uber rich while also cutting healthcare for 24 million hoi polloi.
Second, they are in it for themselves. I understand that any politicians wishes to be reelected, but at what cost. They will sell their mother, even on Mother's Day, if only they can hold on to their seat.
Third, they are not patriotic Americans. They are the ones who will find fault with Obama for not wearing an American flag on his coat lapel or put his hand over his heart for the national anthem. And yet they are the ones who will sell this country to any foreign power at any price as long as their seat is safe.
I could go on and on, but I'm afraid I'll hit the word limit. So let me conclude by saying that there are not enough words in the English language to describe these low lives.

comments.commentBody:
"The Nixon, reagan, and Clinton White Houses had hired quality teams by the time their scandals came. They could continue to function, sort of, even when engulfed."
This is what you get when you hire a person who is ignorant and has no desire to learn. But ignorance aside, the Trump administration is a one-man show who loves to showboat. He will cede no room for anyone else and wants to be seen as the one and only smart person who is in charge. This leads to the kind of vacuum and implosion that you describe.
When Trump decides to show his superiority by having two scoops when the other person is served one, he is acting worse than a two year old. Clearly this is why we have had more scandals and slips in about four months than four presidents have had in four years or more.
This has stopped being funny and is worrisome. And not because we have an ignorant man-child in the WH. It is because we have a gutless, spineless, and heartless GOP that will cow-tow to this Pied Piper. I wish they were the only ones who'd be following him over the ledge and into the sea, but sadly we, the people, are tied to them. And that is worrisome and scary.

comments.commentBody:
Long before the Dunning-Kruger effect was formulated, in a very famous quatrain, Omar Khayyam classified people into four, one being a fool who he recommended we shun. And his basis for determining a fool is as follows:
"He who knows not, and knows not that he knows not, is a fool. Shun him"
Trump fits this definition better than the glove made famous by Johnnie Cochran. Sadly though we cannot shun him. He is here to stay for a wee bit under four years!

comments.commentBody: There is nothing surprising any more in any story about this 2-year old man-child throwing temper tantrums. The surprising thing, or as Bruni calls it "a thing of absolute wonder") is the number of Republicans who have lost their self-respect and credibility straining themselves to rally to his support. I wonder if they know that when he leaves office in 3+ years (unless there is a successful impeachment) they will be left high and dry and called upon to defend their actions. I'm very curious to see the webs they'll weave and the contortions they'll get into to explain themselves. For that I cannot wait.

comments.commentBody:
Trump has violated the anti-nepotism statute. He is more than neck deep in the conflict-of-interest ocean. He has shamelessly used his office and allowed his family to use his office for personal gain.
And, in what must be bitter irony, he goes on a campaign rally (most recently in PA) and gets the crowd to join him in chanting "Lock her up."
It is time that the GOP separate themselves from this man. But with so many Americans in a trance, I'd say "We-the-People" are to be blamed much more.

comments.commentBody:
Many problems are real, but politicians have a tendency to heighten their importance in order to incite common folk and win elections. That, by definition, is the nature of democracy. But of late, as seen in the U.K. and then here in the U.S.A., politicians whip up nonexistent issues or exaggerate their role to limits we've never seen before.
In the U.K. they advertised a shifting of sizable funds into their healthcare system. It turned out to be not true. Here in the U.S.A. they started to issue a barrage of anti-immigrant orders based on nonexistent threats such as the massacre in Bowling Green. It never happened.
The only defense against these excesses is for citizens to be well informed, engage in fact checking, and be attentive to facts. Otherwise we are not any different from the lemmings that follow a leader down the precipice.

comments.commentBody:
A pedestrian is calmly walking on the sidewalk when s/he sees at a distance a car that careens and seems to be out of control and coming in his/her direction.
1. S/he can do nothing and stand still and hope that the car's path veers around (after all it is out of control) leaving the pedestrian essentially unharmed.
2. S/he can jump in some direction and hope that the car's path veers differently from the direction s/he chose leaving the pedestrian essentially unharmed.
Doing nothing can be good, depending on what happens. And doing something may also be good, depending on what happens. The outcome of inaction or taking action depend on what happens in the future; this can only be estimated probabilistically prior to the decision to act or not to act. And depending on subsequent empirical analyses, further corrective action needs to be taken.
But to merely point to past mistakes an hence claim that doing nothing is the only option because doing something may be bad is incorrect. What is more important to realize is that we need to be vigilant and undertake corrective actions at frequent intervals. And that is a very different lesson from the one being advocated in this column.

asset.assetTitle: President Trump Is the Enemy of Their Enemies (04edsall)

taxonomies.name: President Trump Is the Enemy of Their Enemies (04edsall)

comments.commentBody:
This is a static picture of who those Americans are that are socially conservative and find their voice in Trump and hence lend their support to him. But the immigrants who have come in and become US citizens and the youth who will turn of voting age in the next four years are likely to be more liberal in their social values. And this may not bode well for Trump or candidates like him.
In other words I do expect the demographic shift to be substantial enough to make Trump and his ilk obsolete. What happened in 2016 is a combination of many forces that are unlikely to come together again in 2020.

asset.taxonomy: opinion/On the Power of Being Awful (01krugman)
asset.assetTitle: On the Power of Being Awful (01krugman)

taxonomies.name: On the Power of Being Awful (01krugman)

comments.commentBody:
It is often said that perception is reality. I have interpreted that to mean that I'll feel good if I think I'm feeling good. And Trump, to his credit, has been feeding a lot of "feel good" experiences to his voters.
For one, about 700 jobs were saved in Indiana after a huge tax subsidy was underwritten by Indian tax payers. But to Trump supporters it felt like he accosted Carrier and negotiated successfully. From this they extrapolate and believe that he is the one to save jobs across the country.
When Assad used chemical weapons on his own people, what did Trump do? He ordered a raining of missiles. While most analysts noted that the missile attack had very limited value in damaging Assad's assets or capabilities, Trump voters saw a strong man who made America look powerful. They felt like they were on top of the world, once again.
And most recently he skipped the WHCD choosing instead to attend yet another rally. What did his supporters see? They saw a strong man snub the media and instead spent time among them, even though the reason was more likely that he needed adulation rather than ribbing.
Trump supporters see a man in shining armor riding a white horse who they expect will save America. From what is unclear. Or how is also unclear. But they feel it in their bones. And that makes it real.
Until it isn't!

asset.assetTitle: 100 Days of Noise From Donald Trump (29sat1)

taxonomies.name: 100 Days of Noise From Donald Trump (29sat1)

comments.commentBody: It is said that there is but a thin line between tragedy and comedy. And the first 100 days of the Trump administration is a perfect example of that saying. It is indeed very comical to see them bumbling around, huffing and puffing with great bravado. But it masks the tragic situation we are in - defunding of science, climate change, banging the drums of war, and causing unease throughout the world.

comments.commentBody:
Nepotism and corruption are the two pillars of the Trump administration. Let's call it what it is - neporruption.
On a related note, I'd like to ask those of you who have asked those of us who supported Hillary to be kind to those of us who voted for Trump. My simple question: Whatever happened to one of their battle cries 'Corrupt Hillary?" Why should we feel any continued sympathy for the Trump voter who has suddenly developed an amnesia?
